provy.__doc__: This is provy's main namespace. All built-in roles start from this namespace.

core.__doc__: provy's core classes. The modules in this namespace are the ones that run provy.

Role.__doc__:
Base Role class. This is the class that is inherited by all provy's roles. This class provides many utility methods for interacting with the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.register_template_loader('my.full.namespace')
            self.execute('ls /home/myuser', sudo=False, stdout=False)

__methods__.__doc__:
Changes the owner of a given directory. Please be advised that this method is recursive, so all contents of directory will belong to the specified user. Parameters directory - Directory to change owner. owner - User that should own this directory. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.change_dir_owner(directory='/etc/my-path', owner='someuser')

Changes the owner of a given file. Parameters path - Path of the file. owner - User that should own this file. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.change_file_owner(directory='/etc/init.d/someapp',
                                   owner='someuser')

Base cleanup method. This is meant to be overriden and does not do anything. The cleanup method is the method that provy calls after all Roles have been provisioned and is meant to allow Roles to perform any cleaning of resources or finish any pending operations. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def cleanup(self):
            pass

Make sure the specified directory exists in the remote server. Parameters directory - Directory to be created if it does not exist. owner - If specified, the directory will be created under this user, otherwise the currently logged user is the owner. sudo - If specified, the directory is created under the super-user. This is particularly useful in conjunction with the owner parameter, to create folders for the owner where only the super-user can write. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.ensure_dir('/etc/my-path', owner='myuser', sudo=True)

This method is the bread and butter of provy and is a base for most other methods that interact with remote servers. It allows you to perform any shell action in the remote server. It is an abstraction over fabric run and sudo methods. Parameters stdout - Defaults to True. If you specify this argument as False, the standard output of the command execution will not be displayed in the console. sudo - Defaults to False. Specifies whether this command needs to be run as the super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.execute('ls /', stdout=False, sudo=True)

Just an abstraction over execute. This method executes the python code that is passed with python -c. It has the same arguments as execute. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.python_execute('import os; print os.curdir',
                                    stdout=False, sudo=True)

Returns the currently logged user in the remote server. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.context['my-user'] = self.get_logged_user()

Returns the path of a temporary directory in the local machine. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.context['source_dir'] = self.local_temp_dir()

Logs a message to the console with the hour prepended. Parameters msg - Message to log. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.log('Hello World')

Calculates an md5 hash for a given file in the local system. Returns None if file does not exist. Parameters path - Path of the local file. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            hash = self.md5_local('/tmp/my-file')

Calculates an md5 hash for a given file in the remote server. Returns None if file does not exist. Parameters path - Path of the remote file. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            hash = self.md5_remote('/tmp/my-file')

Base provision method. This is meant to be overriden and does not do anything. The provision method of each Role is what provy calls on to provision servers. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            pass

Provisions a role inside your role. This method is the way to call other roles if you don't need to call any methods other than provision. provision_role keeps the context and lifecycle for the current server when calling the role and makes sure it is disposed correctly. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.provision_role(SomeOtherRole)

Puts a file to the remote server. Parameters from_file - Source file in the local system. to_file - Target path in the remote server. sudo - Indicates whether the file should be created by the super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.put('/home/user/my-app', '/etc/init.d/my-app', sudo=True)

Returns the contents of a remote file. Parameters path - File path on the remote server. sudo - Indicates whether the file should be read by a super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            last_update = self.read_remote_file('/tmp/last-update')

Register the <> module as a valid source for templates in jinja2. Jinja2 will look inside a folder called 'templates' in the specified module. It is paramount that this module can be imported by python. The path must be well-known or be a sub-path of the provyfile.py directory. Parameters package_name - full name of the module that jinja2 will try to import. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.register_template_loader('my.full.namespace')

Creates a symlink in the remote server. Parameters from_file - Symlink source. to_file - Symlink target. sudo - Indicates whether the symlink should be created by the super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.remote_symlink('/home/user/my-app', '/etc/init.d/my-app', sudo=True)

Returns the path of a temporary directory in the remote server. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.context['target_dir'] = self.remote_temp_dir()

Removes a file in the remote server. Returns True in the event of the file actually been removed. False otherwise. Parameters path - Path of the remote file. sudo - Indicates whether the file should be removed by the super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.remove_file('/tmp/my-file', sudo=True)

Renders a template with the given options and returns the rendered text. The template_file parameter should be just the name of the file and not the file path. jinja2 will look for templates at the files directory in the provyfile path, as well as in the templates directory of any registered module (check the register_template_loader method). The options parameter will extend the server context, so all context variables (including per-server options) are available to the renderer. Parameters template_file - Template file path in the local system. options - options to be passed to the template. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            contents = self.render('my-template', { 'user': 'heynemann' })

Replaces a file in the remote server with a file from the local system. Parameters from_file - Path in the local system. to_file - Path in the remote system. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.replace_file('/tmp/my-file', '/tmp/my-file')

Makes sure that this role will be cleaned up properly after the server has been provisioned. Call this method in your provision method if you need your role's cleanup method to be called. Warning: If you are using the proper ways of calling roles (provision_role, using) in your role, you do not need to call this method. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.schedule_cleanup()

One of the most used methods in provy. This method renders a template, then if the contents differ from the remote server (or the file does not exist at the remote server), it sends the results there. Again, combining the parameters sudo and owner you can have files that belong to an user that is not a super-user in places that only a super-user can reach. Returns True if the file was updated, False otherwise. Parameters from_file - Template file in the local system. to_file - Target path in the remote server. owner - Owner for the file in the remote server. options - Dictionary of options that can be used in the template. sudo - Indicates whether the file should be created by the super-user. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.update_file('/home/user/my-app', '/etc/init.d/my-app',
                                owner='my-user', {
                                    'option_a': 1,
                                    'option_b': 2
                                }, sudo=True)

This method should be used when you want to use a different Role inside your own Role methods. It returns a ContextManager object, so this is meant to go inside a with block. Parameters role - Role to be used. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(AptitudeRole) as role:
                role.ensure_package_installed('nginx')

Writes some text to a temporary file and returns the file path. Parameters text - Text to be written to the temp file. Sample Usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            path = self.write_to_temp_file('some random text')
            self.put_file(path, '/tmp/some-file')

centos.__doc__: Roles in this namespace are suited for provisioning centos servers.

package.__doc__: Roles in this namespace are meant to enable users to install packages using package managers such as Yum or Pip in CentOS distributions.

PipRole.__doc__:
This role provides package management operations with PIP within CentOS distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                role.ensure_package_installed('django', version='1.1.1')

__methods__.__doc__:
Makes sure the package is installed with the specified version (Latest if None specified). This method does not verify and upgrade the package on subsequent provisions, though. Use ensure_package_up_to_date for this purpose instead. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to install. version - If specified, installs this version of the package. Installs latest version otherwise. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                role.ensure_package_installed('django', version='1.1.1')

Makes sure the package is installed and up-to-date with the latest version. This method verifies if there is a newer version for this package every time the server is provisioned. If a new version is found, it is installed. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to install. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                role.ensure_package_is_up_to_date('django')

Returns the latest available version of the package at the Python Package Index. If package is not available, returns None. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                version = role.get_package_remote_version('django')
                latest = role.get_package_latest_version('django')
                if version != latest:
                    # do something
                    # this check is not needed if you use ensure_package_up_to_date.

Returns the version of the package currently installed via PIP in the remote server. If package is not installed, returns None. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                version = role.get_package_remote_version('django')
                if version and version == '1.1.1':
                    # do something

Returns True if the given package is installed via pip in the remote server, False otherwise. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                if role.is_package_installed('django', version='1.1.1'):
                    # do something

Returns True if there is an update for the given package in the Python Package Index, False otherwise. Parameters package_name - Name of the package to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(PipRole) as role:
                if role.package_can_be_updated('django'):
                    # do something
                    # this check is not needed if you use ensure_package_up_to_date.

Installs pip dependencies. This method should be called upon if overriden in base classes, or PIP won't work properly in the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.provision_role(PipRole) # does not need to be called if using with block.

UserRole.__doc__:
This role provides many utility methods for user management operations within CentOS distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_user('myuser', identified_by='mypass', is_admin=True)

__methods__.__doc__:
Ensures that a given user group is present in the remote server. Parameters group_name - Name of the group to create. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_group('users-group')

Ensures that a given user is present in the remote server. Parameters username - Name of the user. identified_by - Password that the user will use to login to the remote server. If set to None, the user will not have a password. home_folder - Defaults to /home/<username>. Specifies the user's home folder. default_script - Defaults to /bin/sh. Sets the user's default script, the one that will execute commands per default when logging in. group - Defaults to the name of the user. Group that this user belongs to. If the group does not exist it is created prior to user creation. is_admin - If set to True the user is added to the 'admin' user group as well. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_user('myuser', identified_by='mypass', is_admin=True)

Returns True if the given group exist, False otherwise. Parameters group_name - Name of the group to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.group_exists('usersgroup'):
                    # do something

Returns True if the given user exist, False otherwise. Parameters username - Name of the user to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.user_exists('myuser'):
                    # do something

Returns True if the given user is in the given group, False otherwise. Parameters username - Name of the user to verify. group_name - Name of the group to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.user_in_group('myuser', 'mygroup'):
                    # do something

VarnishRole.__doc__:
This role provides utility methods for Varnish configuration and execution within Debian distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(VarnishRole) as role:
                role.ensure_vcl('default.vcl', owner='user')
                role.ensure_conf('default_varnish', owner='user')

__methods__.__doc__:
Restarts Varnish if it needs to be restarted (any changes made during this server's provisioning). Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(VarnishRole) as role:
                role.cleanup() # No need to call this if using a with block.

Ensures that Varnish's configuration file at the specified path is up-to-date. Parameters template - The name of the VCL template file. varnish_conf_path - The path that the configuration file will be in the remote server. Defaults to /etc/default/varnish. options - Dictionary of options to pass to the configuration template file. Extends context. owner - Owner of the configuration file at the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(VarnishRole) as role:
                role.ensure_conf('default_varnish', owner='user')

Ensures that Varnish is restarted on cleanup phase. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(VarnishRole) as role:
                role.ensure_restart() # No need to call this if using a with block.

Ensures that the VCL file at the specified path is up-to-date. Parameters template - The name of the VCL template file. varnish_vcl_path - The path that the VCL file will be in the remote server. Defaults to /etc/varnish/default.vcl. options - Dictionary of options to pass to the VCL template file. Extends context. owner - Owner of the VCL file at the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(VarnishRole) as role:
                role.ensure_vcl('default.vcl', owner='user')

Installs Varnish and its dependencies. This method should be called upon if overriden in base classes, or Varnish won't work properly in the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.provision_role(VarnishRole) # does not need to be called if using with block.

SupervisorRole.__doc__:
This role provides supervisor monitoring utilities for Debian distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(SupervisorRole) as role:
                role.config(
                    config_file_directory='/home/backend',
                    log_file='/home/backend/logs/supervisord.log',
                    user=self.context['supervisor-user']
                )

                with role.with_program('website') as program:
                    program.directory = '/home/backend/provy/tests/functional'
                    program.command = 'python website.py 800%(process_num)s'
                    program.number_of_processes = 4

                    program.log_folder = '/home/backend/logs'

UserRole.__doc__:
This role provides many utility methods for user management operations within Debian distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_user('myuser', identified_by='mypass', is_admin=True)

__methods__.__doc__:
Ensures that a given user group is present in the remote server. Parameters group_name - Name of the group to create. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_group('users-group')

Ensures that a given user is present in the remote server. Parameters username - Name of the user. identified_by - Password that the user will use to login to the remote server. If set to None, the user will not have a password. home_folder - Defaults to /home/<username>. Specifies the user's home folder. default_script - Defaults to /bin/sh. Sets the user's default script, the one that will execute commands per default when logging in. group - Defaults to the name of the user. Group that this user belongs to. If the group does not exist it is created prior to user creation. is_admin - If set to True the user is added to the 'admin' user group as well. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                role.ensure_user('myuser', identified_by='mypass', is_admin=True)

Returns True if the given group exist, False otherwise. Parameters group_name - Name of the group to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.group_exists('usersgroup'):
                    # do something

Returns True if the given user exist, False otherwise. Parameters username - Name of the user to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.user_exists('myuser'):
                    # do something

Returns True if the given user is in the given group, False otherwise. Parameters username - Name of the user to verify. group_name - Name of the group to verify. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(UserRole) as role:
                if role.user_in_group('myuser', 'mygroup'):
                    # do something

vcs.__doc__: Roles in this namespace relate to Version Control Systems support in Debian distributions, such as git, svn or mercurial.

GitRole.__doc__:
This role provides utility methods for Git repositories management within Debian distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(GitRole) as role:
                role.ensure_repository('git://github.com/heynemann/provy.git',
                                       '/home/user/provy',
                                       owner='user',
                                       branch='some-branch')

__methods__.__doc__:
Makes sure the repository is create in the remote server. This method does not update the repository or perform any operations in it. It is merely used to ensure that the repository exists in the specified path. Parameters repo - Git repository url. path - Path to create the local repository. owner - User that owns the repository directory. branch - If specified, the given branch will be checked-out, otherwise it stays in the master branch. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(GitRole) as role:
                role.ensure_repository('git://github.com/heynemann/provy.git',
                                       '/home/user/provy',
                                       owner='user',
                                       branch='some-branch')

Installs git dependencies. This method should be called upon if overriden in base classes, or Git won't work properly in the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.provision_role(GitRole) # does not need to be called if using with block.

web.__doc__: Roles in this namespace are meant to configure either Web Servers (apache, nginx) or Web App Servers (tornado, django, rails) in Debian distributions.

NginxRole.__doc__:
This role provides Nginx web server management utilities for Debian distributions. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.ensure_conf(conf_template='nginx.conf')
                role.ensure_site_disabled('default')
                role.create_site(site='my-site', template='my-site')
                role.ensure_site_enabled('my-site')

__methods__.__doc__:
Restarts nginx if any changes have been made.
There's no need to call this method manually.

Adds a website with the specified template to Nginx list of available sites. Warning: Do not forget to call ensure_site_enabled after a call to create_site, or your site won't be enabled. Parameters site - Name of the site to enable. template - Site configuration template. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.create_site(site='my-site', template='my-site')

Ensures that nginx configuration is up-to-date with the specified template. Parameters conf_template - Name of the template for nginx.conf. options - Dictionary of options passed to template. Extends context. nginx_conf_path - Path of the nginx configuration file. Defaults to /etc/nginx/nginx.conf. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.ensure_conf(conf_template='nginx.conf')

Ensures that nginx gets restarted on cleanup. There's no need to call this method as any changes to nginx will trigger it. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.ensure_restart()

Ensures that the specified site is removed from nginx list of enabled sites. Parameters site - Name of the site to disable. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.ensure_site_disabled('default')

Ensures that a symlink is created for the specified site at nginx list of enabled sites from the list of available sites. Parameters site - Name of the site to enable. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.ensure_site_enabled('my-site')

Installs Nginx dependencies. This method should be called upon if overriden in base classes, or Nginx won't work properly in the remote server. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            self.provision_role(NginxRole) # does not need to be called if using with block.

Forcefully restarts nginx. Sample usage 
    class MySampleRole(Role):
        def provision(self):
            with self.using(NginxRole) as role:
                role.restart()
